_header: After the stormy time ceasing the rain
Note:
Possibly Chaucer’s Wretched Engendering; see Brown (1935)
XBrown, Carleton Fairchild. “Chaucer’s Wreched Engendring.” PMLA 50 (1935): 997-1011, 997-1101; Brown (1937)
XBrown, Beatrice Daw. “Chaucer’s Wretched engendrynge.” Modern Philology 35 (1937-38): 325-33.

BodAsh59.First Lines:
Affter þe stormy tyme cessinge þe rayneWhane for
                    þabsence of colde þeorte is fayneAnd þe qwicke thinges
                    resceyve þeire vygoureTrees and herbes bringen forþe leeff and
                    floure…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…If þowe do þus þane shal þy soule
                    weendeTo hevens blisse which þat haþenoon ende
BodAsh59.Attributed Author:
…made by þe Religious man Lidegate daun Johan þe Munk of
                    Bury (f. 49)
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here nowe foloweþe an holy meditacioun made by þe Religious man
                    Lidegate daun Johan þe Munk of Bury (f. 49)

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Affter þe stormy tyme cessing þe raynWhane for
                    þabsence of colde þeorþe is faynAnd þe qwyck thinges
                    resceyue vygourAnd trees bringen foorþe leef and
                    flour…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…If þou do þus þane shal þy soule weendeTo
                    heuene blisse which þat haþe noon eende
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Nowe here filoweþe an holy medytacion (p. 111); A devoute Meditacion
                    (RT, 111-116)
CamTCC600.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems.
EETS
         e.s. 107 (1911; repr. 1961): 43-8.
